In a letter to Böhlendorf, Hölderlin praises Homer’s ability to “appropriate what is foreign,” something completely different from the ability to experience what is one’s own and to experience the foreign solely for the sake of what is one’s own. The tenor of that letter, which Heidegger may have been thinking of, is the opposite of what Heidegger claims for it: “But once again I assert, and offer for your examination and your use: with the advance of culture, the national in the specific sense will be given less and less priority
